name: Housing Affordability Stress Map
rationale: Every analyst and investor cares about affordability. Granular county-level data provides a unique competitive edge over national reports. Requires new but easily accessible FRED series (Home Price/Income by county).

name: Construction Pipeline Pressure Index
rationale: A powerful leading indicator for housing supply/demand imbalance. Identifies metro areas where builder sentiment (permits) diverges from real activity (starts), signaling bottlenecks. Requires local PERMIT/HOUST data.

name: The "Rate-Lock" Effect Visualizer
rationale: Directly addresses a major current theme in the housing market. Simple to build with existing mortgage rate data and helps explain low housing inventory. A strong narrative tool.

name: Credit Risk & Housing Downturn Map
rationale: Extremely high alpha potential, as it could be a leading indicator for regional housing crashes. However, requires sourcing difficult-to-get county-level mortgage delinquency data. High effort, low confidence.

name: Rental Market Pressure Index
rationale: Identifies rental markets under stress, which is a key input for inflation analysis and REIT investors. Requires sourcing new metro-level CPI for Rent data from FRED.

name: Gentrification Leading Indicators
rationale: A map that correlates changes in building permits for multi-family homes with changes in local consumer spending data. A powerful but complex signal requiring highly granular, non-standard data.

name: Climate Risk vs. Property Value
rationale: A very modern and high-value insight. Involves joining property value data with climate risk data (e.g., flood plains, wildfire zones from FEMA/NRCan). Requires significant new geospatial data sourcing.

name: Commercial vs. Residential Divergence
rationale: Analyzes the post-pandemic health of Commercial Real Estate (CRE) vs. Residential. Requires sourcing CRE-specific data (e.g., vacancy rates, lease rates) and joining by metro area (CBSA).

name: Canada vs. US: Provincial/State Affordability
rationale: A great comparative analysis tool. Requires sourcing Canadian-specific data (e.g., Teranet Home Price Index, StatCan income data) and creating a normalized affordability metric.

name: Infrastructure Impact on Property Values
rationale: Long-term analysis. Involves mapping new infrastructure projects (e.g., highways, transit lines) and measuring the change in property values in adjacent census tracts over time. Very high effort.

name: Real Estate
rationale: Massive market. Our new PostGIS data is a huge, unique advantage. We can immediately correlate `HOUST`, `PERMIT`, and `MORTGAGE30US` with county/tract boundaries. Insight: "Housing Stress Index by County".

name: Government / Macro
rationale: Core to all users. We have the most data here already (`GDP`, `CPI`, `UNRATE`). However, generating truly *unique* insights is harder as this space is crowded. Insight: "The Real Fed Funds Rate".

name: Financials
rationale: Highly relevant audience. We can analyze bank health by combining `FEDFUNDS`, the yield curve (`T10Y2Y`), and financial stress (`STLFSI3`). Requires new data but is very powerful. Insight: "Predicting Financial Stress with Yield Curve Inversions".

name: Industrials
rationale: Good for analyzing the "real" economy. We can use `INDPRO`, `PAYEMS`, and new supply chain data (`GSCPI`). Less unique than Real Estate. Insight: "Supply Chain Pressure vs. Industrial Production".

name: Consumer Discretionary
rationale: Relies heavily on consumer sentiment (`UMCSENT`) and retail sales (`RSXFS`). High potential if we add credit card data. Insight: "Consumer Sentiment vs. Actual Spending by region".

name: Energy
rationale: High alpha potential, especially when combined with geopolitics. However, requires sourcing new, specific commodity price data (e.g., WTI, Henry Hub), which we don't have. Insight: "FXUSDCAD vs. WTI Crude Price".

name: Materials
rationale: Similar to Energy, requires new, specific commodity price data (e.g., lumber, copper). Niche but potentially valuable. Insight: "Lumber Prices vs. Housing Starts".

name: Information Technology
rationale: Analysis requires deep, company-specific data (EDGAR) or high-frequency tech-sector data. High effort with our current stack. Insight: "Semiconductor Production vs. NASDAQ".

name: Communication Services
rationale: Very difficult to analyze with macro data alone. Relies heavily on company-specific metrics (e.g., subscriber growth). Low-priority for now.

name: Health Care
rationale: Highly specialized sector. Analysis requires deep regulatory and clinical trial knowledge, not just macro data. Low-priority.

name: Utilities
rationale: A stable, regulated sector. Can be analyzed with interest rate and energy price data, but alpha potential is lower. Low-priority.

name: Consumer Staples
rationale: Similar to Utilities, a defensive sector. Less sensitive to the macro trends we currently track. Low-priority.
